message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Quantifying the Sim-To-Real Gap in UAV Disturbance Rejection
Paper Abstract: Due to the safety risks and training sample inefficiency, it is often preferred to develop controllers in simulation. However, minor differences between the simulation and the real world can cause a significant sim-to-real gap. This gap can reduce the effectiveness of the developed controller. In this paper, we examine a case study of transferring an octorotor reinforcement learning controller from simulation to the real world. First, we quantify the effectiveness of the real-world transfer by examining safety metrics. We find that although there is a noticeable (around 100%) increase in deviation in real flights, this deviation may not be considered unsafe, as it will be within > 2m safety corridors. Then, we estimate the densities of the measurement distributions and compare the Jensen-Shannon divergences of simulated and real measurements. From this, we show that the vehicle’s orientation is significantly different between simulated and real flights. We attribute this to a different flight mode in real flights where the vehicle turns to face the next waypoint. We also find that the reinforcement learning controller actions appear to correctly counteract disturbance forces. Then, we analyze the errors of a measurement autoencoder and state transition model neural network applied to real data. We find that these models further reinforce the difference between the simulated and real attitude control, showing the errors directly on the flight paths. Finally, we discuss important lessons learned in the sim-to-real transfer of our controller.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Jensen-Shannon divergence:

## Overview

The Jensen–Shannon divergence, named after Johan Jensen and Claude Shannon, is a method of measuring the similarity between two probability distributions.(no content)It is also known as information radius (IRad) or total divergence to the average.

## Key Properties

The Jensen–Shannon divergence is bounded by 1 for two discrete probability distributions, given that one uses the base 2 logarithm. This means it produces values between 0 and 1, making it easier to interpret compared to some other divergence measures.

## Mathematical Foundation

The value λ = 0.5 gives the Jensen–Shannon divergence, defined by D_JS = 1/2 D_KL(P||M) + 1/2 D_KL(Q||M), where the divergence is calculated as a symmetric combination of Kullback-Leibler divergences.

## Applications

The Jensen–Shannon divergence has been applied in bioinformatics and genome comparison, in protein surface comparison, in the social sciences, in the quantitative study of history, in fire experiments, and in machine learning.

## Generalizations

The geometric Jensen–Shannon divergence (or G-Jensen–Shannon divergence) yields a closed-form formula for divergence between two Gaussian distributions by taking the geometric mean.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Jensen–Shannon divergence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jensen–Shannon_divergence"},{"title":"Kullback–Leibler divergence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kullback–Leibler_divergence"},{"title":"Talk:Jensen–Shannon divergence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Jensen–Shannon_divergence"},{"title":"Statistical distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_distance"},{"title":"Divergence (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divergent"},{"title":"Rényi entropy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R%C3%A9nyi_entropy"},{"title":"Jensen's inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jensen's_inequality"},{"title":"Mutual information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information"},{"title":"Divergence (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divergence_(statistics)"},{"title":"Inequalities in information theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inequalities_in_information_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Jensen-Shannon divergence:

## Overview

The Jensen–Shannon divergence, named after Johan Jensen and Claude Shannon, is a method of measuring the similarity between two probability distributions.(no content)It is also known as information radius (IRad) or total divergence to the average.

## Key Properties

The Jensen–Shannon divergence is bounded by 1 for two discrete probability distributions, given that one uses the base 2 logarithm. This means it produces values between 0 and 1, making it easier to interpret compared to some other divergence measures.

## Mathematical Foundation

The value λ = 0.5 gives the Jensen–Shannon divergence, defined by D_JS = 1/2 D_KL(P||M) + 1/2 D_KL(Q||M), where the divergence is calculated as a symmetric combination of Kullback-Leibler divergences.

## Applications

The Jensen–Shannon divergence has been applied in bioinformatics and genome comparison, in protein surface comparison, in the social sciences, in the quantitative study of history, in fire experiments, and in machine learning.

## Generalizations

The geometric Jensen–Shannon divergence (or G-Jensen–Shannon divergence) yields a closed-form formula for divergence between two Gaussian distributions by taking the geometric mean.

## Autoencoder Neural Network

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about autoencoders:

### Definition and Basic Function

An autoencoder is a type of artificial neural network used to learn efficient codings of unlabeled data (unsupervised learning).(no content)An autoencoder learns two functions: an encoding function that transforms the input data, and a decoding function that recreates the input data from the encoded representation.

### Purpose and Applications

The autoencoder learns an efficient representation (encoding) for a set of data, typically for dimensionality reduction, to generate lower-dimensional embeddings for subsequent use by other machine learning algorithms.(no content)Autoencoders are applied to many problems, including facial recognition, feature detection, anomaly detection, and learning the meaning of words.

### Architecture

An autoencoder is similar to the multilayer perceptron (MLP) – with an input layer, an output layer and one or more hidden layers connecting them. However, the output layer has the same number of units as the input layer.

### Variants

Variants include regularized autoencoders (sparse, denoising and contractive autoencoders), which are effective in learning representations for subsequent classification tasks, and variational autoencoders, which can be used as generative models.

Additionally, a variational autoencoder (VAE) is an artificial neural network architecture introduced by Diederik P. Kingma and Max Welling in 2013.

## Reinforcement Learning - Search Results

I've found comprehensive information about reinforcement learning. Here's an overview based on the search results:

### Definition
Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

### How It Works
While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

### Key Characteristics
The environment is typically stated in the form of a Markov decision process, as many reinforcement learning algorithms use dynamic programming techniques.(no content)Two elements make reinforcement learning powerful: the use of samples to optimize performance, and the use of function approximation to deal with large environments.

### Applications
It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

### Deep Reinforcement Learning
Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about disturbance rejection in control theory:

## Overview

Disturbance rejection is a key control objective, such as addressing hills in cruise control systems.

## Key Approaches to Disturbance Rejection

**1. Closed-Loop Control (Feedback)**

Closed-loop controllers provide disturbance rejection, such as handling hills in cruise control. Classical control theory uses feedback in closed-loop controllers which control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

**2. PID Controllers**

The integral term in PID controllers permits the rejection of a step disturbance, which is often a striking specification in process control.

**3. Feedforward Control**

A feedforward control system uses sensors to detect disturbances affecting the system and then applies an additional input to minimize the effect of the disturbance, requiring a mathematical model of the system. With feedforward control, disturbances are measured and accounted for before they have time to affect the system.

**4. Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ADRC)**

Active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) is a model-free control technique used for designing controllers for systems with unknown dynamics and external disturbances. ADRC offers a solution by real-time disturbance estimation and compensation, without needing a detailed model.

## Role of Loop Gain

From the closed-loop transfer function perspective, high open-loop gain leads to substantial disturbance rejection in the face of system parameter uncertainty.

Links: [{"title":"Active disturbance rejection control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_disturbance_rejection_control"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control_theory"},{"title":"Category:Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Control_theory"},{"title":"Category:Systems articles in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Systems_articles_in_control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about disturbance rejection in control theory:

## Overview

Disturbance rejection is a key control objective, such as addressing hills in cruise control systems.

## Key Approaches to Disturbance Rejection

**1. Closed-Loop Control (Feedback)**

Closed-loop controllers provide disturbance rejection, such as handling hills in cruise control. Classical control theory uses feedback in closed-loop controllers which control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

**2. PID Controllers**

The integral term in PID controllers permits the rejection of a step disturbance, which is often a striking specification in process control.

**3. Feedforward Control**

A feedforward control system uses sensors to detect disturbances affecting the system and then applies an additional input to minimize the effect of the disturbance, requiring a mathematical model of the system. With feedforward control, disturbances are measured and accounted for before they have time to affect the system.

**4. Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ADRC)**

Active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) is a model-free control technique used for designing controllers for systems with unknown dynamics and external disturbances. ADRC offers a solution by real-time disturbance estimation and compensation, without needing a detailed model.

## Role of Loop Gain

From the closed-loop transfer function perspective, high open-loop gain leads to substantial disturbance rejection in the face of system parameter uncertainty.

I've completed the web search for "Unmanned aerial vehicle UAV". Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Technical Characteristics

UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs). A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## Historical Development

UAVs were originally developed through the twentieth century for military missions.(no content)The earliest attempt at a powered UAV was A. M. Low's "Aerial Target" in 1916.(no content)Over 400 de Havilland 82 Queen Bee aerial targets went into service in 1935.

## Military and Commercial Applications

As of 2012, the United States Air Force employed 7,494 UAVs. The Central Intelligence Agency also operated UAVs. By 2013 at least 50 countries used UAVs.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations.

The search results provide comprehensive information about UAVs, their characteristics, history, and current applications in military and civilian contexts.

Web search results for query: "Neural network state transition model"

Links: [{"title":"Liquid state machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liquid_state_machine"},{"title":"Recurrent neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recurrent_neural_network"},{"title":"Hidden Markov model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hidden_Markov_model"},{"title":"Time delay neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_delay_neural_network"},{"title":"Mathematics of neural networks in machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics_of_neural_networks_in_machine_learning"},{"title":"Echo state network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_state_network"},{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Long short-term memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_short-term_memory"},{"title":"Neural network quantum states - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_quantum_states"},{"title":"Augmented transition network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augmented_transition_network"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of neural network state transition models:

## Key Concepts

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) are designed for processing sequential data, such as text, speech, and time series, where the order of elements is important. Unlike feedforward neural networks, which process inputs independently, RNNs utilize recurrent connections, where the output of a neuron at one time step is fed back as input to the network at the next time step.(no content)The fundamental building block of RNN is the recurrent unit, which maintains a hidden state—a form of memory that is updated at each time step based on the current input and the previous hidden state.

## Types of Networks

Several specific architectures incorporate state transition mechanisms:

**Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)**: LSTM is a type of recurrent neural network (RNN) aimed at mitigating the vanishing gradient problem commonly encountered by traditional RNNs.(no content)An LSTM unit is typically composed of a cell and three gates: an input gate, an output gate, and a forget gate. The cell remembers values over arbitrary time intervals, and the gates regulate the flow of information into and out of the cell.

**Echo State Networks**: An echo state network (ESN) is a type of reservoir computer that uses a recurrent neural network with a sparsely connected hidden layer. The connectivity and weights of hidden neurons are fixed and randomly assigned. The weights of output neurons can be learned so that the network can produce or reproduce specific temporal patterns.

**Hybrid Approaches**: A recurrent neural network, specifically a reservoir network, can be employed to capture the evolution of the temporal dynamics in observed data. This information, encoded in the form of a high-dimensional vector, is used as a conditioning variable of the HMM state transition probabilities.

Links: [{"title":"Waypoint - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waypoint"},{"title":"Vertical navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_navigation"},{"title":"Area navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Area_navigation"},{"title":"Flight management system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_management_computer"},{"title":"Inertial navigation system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inertial_navigation_system"},{"title":"ArduPilot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ArduPilot"},{"title":"Navigate on Autopilot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Navigate_on_Autopilot&redirect=no"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Tesla Autopilot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_Autopilot"},{"title":"Satellite navigation software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satellite_navigation_software"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about waypoint navigation autopilot:

## Overview

A waypoint is a point or place on a route or line of travel that represents coordinates specifying one's position on the globe at the end of each "leg" (stage) of a journey.

## Aviation Applications

GPS receivers are integrated into autopilot or flight management systems to aid the pilot in control of an aircraft.(no content)In air navigation, waypoints most often consist of a series of abstract GPS points that create artificial airways—"highways in the sky"—created specifically for purposes of air navigation.

In modern aircraft, the FMS calculates the course to follow, and the pilot can follow this course manually or the autopilot can be set to follow the course.(no content)The FMS mode is normally called LNAV (Lateral Navigation) for the lateral flight plan and VNAV (vertical navigation) for the vertical flight plan, with VNAV providing speed and pitch or altitude targets and LNAV providing roll steering command to the autopilot.

## Historical Context

An early example was the Delco Carousel, which allowed pilots to enter 9 waypoints at a time and then guided the aircraft from one waypoint to the next using an INS to determine aircraft position and velocity.

## Other Applications

GPS waypoint navigation uses GNSS to navigate to an intermediate location on a travel path. Additionally, marine navigation software often has option to control external autopilot for automated boat navigation.

In modern aircraft, the FMS calculates the course to follow, and the pilot can follow this course manually or the autopilot can be set to follow the course.(no content)The FMS mode is normally called LNAV (Lateral Navigation) for the lateral flight plan and VNAV (vertical navigation) for the vertical flight plan, with VNAV providing speed and pitch or altitude targets and LNAV providing roll steering command to the autopilot.

## Historical Context

An early example was the Delco Carousel, which allowed pilots to enter 9 waypoints at a time and then guided the aircraft from one waypoint to the next using an INS to determine aircraft position and velocity.

## Other Applications

GPS waypoint navigation uses GNSS to navigate to an intermediate location on a travel path. Additionally, marine navigation software often has option to control external autopilot for automated boat navigation.

Web search results for query: "Sim-to-real transfer learning robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Robotics simulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics_simulator"},{"title":"Vision-language-action model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vision-language-action_model"},{"title":"Robot learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_learning"},{"title":"AirSim - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AirSim"},{"title":"Cognitive robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_robotics"},{"title":"Transfer learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_learning"},{"title":"CoppeliaSim - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CoppeliaSim"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Instructional simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instructional_simulation"},{"title":"Microsoft Robotics Developer Studio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Robotics_Developer_Studio"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about sim-to-real transfer learning in robotics:

## Overview

A robotics simulator is a simulator used to create an application for a physical robot without depending on the physical machine, thus saving cost and time.(no content)In some cases, such applications can be transferred onto a physical robot without modification.

## Benefits of Simulation-Based Learning

The use of a robotics simulator to develop a robotics control program is highly recommended regardless of whether a physical robot is available or not, as the simulator allows for robotics programs to be conveniently written and debugged off-line with the final version of the program tested on a physical robot.(no content)Simulations with the use of virtual models of the working environment and the robots themselves can offer advantages to both the company and programmer, and by using a simulation, costs are reduced.

## Training Data from Simulations

In modern robotics learning approaches, the training dataset consists of robot demonstrations which may be gathered from real robots, human teleoperation, or even synthetically generated in a simulation environment.

## Challenges

Sensor-based robot actions are much more difficult to simulate and/or to program off-line, since the robot motion depends on instantaneous sensor readings in the real world. Additionally, the success of off-line programming depends on how similar the physical environment of a robot is to a simulated environment.

Several robotics simulators support this approach, including AirSim, an open-source, cross-platform simulator for drones and ground vehicles built on Epic Games' Unreal Engine 4.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Attitude control aircraft flight"

Links: [{"title":"Flight control surfaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_control_surfaces"},{"title":"Spacecraft attitude determination and control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spacecraft_attitude_control"},{"title":"Flight control modes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_control_modes"},{"title":"Aircraft flight dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_flight_dynamics"},{"title":"Aircraft flight control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_flight_control_system"},{"title":"Flight dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_dynamics"},{"title":"Reaction control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaction_control_system"},{"title":"Visual flight - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_flight_(aeronautics)"},{"title":"Attitude indicator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attitude_indicator"},{"title":"Autopilot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autopilot"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about attitude control in aircraft flight:

## Overview

Flight control surfaces are aerodynamic devices allowing a pilot to adjust and control the aircraft's flight attitude, with the primary function of controlling the aircraft's movement along the three axes of rotation.

## The Three Axes of Control

A conventional fixed-wing aircraft uses three primary flight control surfaces– aileron, rudder and elevator to control the roll, yaw, and pitch respectively. These correspond to:

- **Pitch**: Rotation about the transverse axis passing through an aircraft from wingtip to wingtip, which changes the vertical direction that the aircraft's nose is pointing, and is controlled by elevators.

- **Roll**: Rotation about the longitudinal axis passing through the aircraft from nose to tail.

- **Yaw**: Controlled by the rudder to manage rotational movement about the vertical axis.

## Control Systems

Control systems adjust the orientation of a vehicle about its center of gravity, with control surfaces that when deflected, generate a moment about the center of gravity which rotates the aircraft in pitch, roll, and yaw.(no content)Generally, the primary cockpit flight controls include a control yoke, centre stick or side-stick, which governs the aircraft's roll and pitch, and rudder pedals which control yaw by moving the rudder.

## Trimming

Trimming controls allow a pilot to balance the lift and drag being produced by the wings and control surfaces over a wide range of load and airspeed, reducing the effort required to adjust or maintain a desired flight attitude.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Jensen Shannon divergence"

Links: [{"title":"Jensen–Shannon divergence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jensen–Shannon_divergence"},{"title":"Kullback–Leibler divergence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kullback–Leibler_divergence"},{"title":"Talk:Jensen–Shannon divergence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Jensen–Shannon_divergence"},{"title":"Statistical distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_distance"},{"title":"Divergence (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divergent"},{"title":"Rényi entropy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R%C3%A9nyi_entropy"},{"title":"Mutual information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information"},{"title":"Divergence (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divergence_(statistics)"},{"title":"Jensen's inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jensen's_inequality"},{"title":"Inequalities in information theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inequalities_in_information_theory"}]

Here are the search results for Jensen-Shannon divergence:

## Definition

The Jensen–Shannon divergence, named after Johan Jensen and Claude Shannon, is a method of measuring the similarity between two probability distributions.(no content)It is also known as information radius (IRad) or total divergence to the average.

## Key Characteristics

The Jensen–Shannon divergence is bounded by 1 for two discrete probability distributions, given that one uses the base 2 logarithm.(no content)The Jensen–Shannon divergence, like all f-divergences, is locally proportional to the Fisher information metric and is similar to the Hellinger metric (in the sense that it induces the same affine connection on a statistical manifold).

## Applications

The Jensen–Shannon divergence has been applied in bioinformatics and genome comparison, in protein surface comparison, in the social sciences, in the quantitative study of history, in fire experiments, and in machine learning.

## Generalizations

The geometric Jensen–Shannon divergence (or G-Jensen–Shannon divergence) yields a closed-form formula for divergence between two Gaussian distributions by taking the geometric mean. Additionally, the generalization of probability distributions on density matrices allows to define quantum Jensen–Shannon divergence (QJSD).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here are the search results for Jensen-Shannon divergence:

## Definition

The Jensen–Shannon divergence, named after Johan Jensen and Claude Shannon, is a method of measuring the similarity between two probability distributions.(no content)It is also known as information radius (IRad) or total divergence to the average.

## Key Characteristics

The Jensen–Shannon divergence is bounded by 1 for two discrete probability distributions, given that one uses the base 2 logarithm.(no content)The Jensen–Shannon divergence, like all f-divergences, is locally proportional to the Fisher information metric and is similar to the Hellinger metric (in the sense that it induces the same affine connection on a statistical manifold).

## Applications

The Jensen–Shannon divergence has been applied in bioinformatics and genome comparison, in protein surface comparison, in the social sciences, in the quantitative study of history, in fire experiments, and in machine learning.

## Generalizations

The geometric Jensen–Shannon divergence (or G-Jensen–Shannon divergence) yields a closed-form formula for divergence between two Gaussian distributions by taking the geometric mean. Additionally, the generalization of probability distributions on density matrices allows to define quantum Jensen–Shannon divergence (QJSD).
